TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}
TEXT.source: told by Giłgiław of Vałulu village

S.FORM: izua za mareqali.
izoa za mareqali.
S.TRANSL: There were two (young) friends.

S.FORM: "ari kikasivi, qalian," aya tiamadju.
"ari kikasivi, qalian," aya tiamadjo.
S.TRANSL: They said to one another: “Let’s go and collect wood, friend.”

S.FORM: ka zemuker i vavua patsun ta za kamaya na qaliqali.
ka zemoker i vavoa pacon ta za kamaya na qaliqali.
S.TRANSL: When they got to the fields, they saw some mango trees belonging to other people.

S.FORM: malulum anga.
malolom anga.
S.TRANSL: The fruit was ripe,

S.FORM: manu sauram aza mareqali.
mano saoram aza mareqali.
S.TRANSL: so the friends wanted to eat it.

S.FORM: manu vaik a tsemakaw.
mano vaik a cemakaw.
S.TRANSL: So they went to steal it,

S.FORM: łevavaw ta za kamaya a mareqali.
ljevavaw ta za kamaya a mareqali.
S.TRANSL: and got up in the mango tree,

S.FORM: keman izua i vavaw.
keman izoa i vavaw.
S.TRANSL: and ate mangoes up there.

S.FORM: ka masilanga tiamadju, "ari, qalian, vaiki anga.
ka masilanga tiamadjo, "ari, qalian, vaiki anga.
S.TRANSL: When they had had enough, they said: “Come on, friend, let’s go.

S.FORM: marekutj itjen.
marekotj itjen.
S.TRANSL: We’re afraid,

S.FORM: mana nu djumaken itjen," aya tja mareqali.
mana no djomaken itjen," aya tja mareqali.
S.TRANSL: in case we’re found out.”

S.FORM: manu inika makaya sema teku a małeḍusa.
mano inika makaya sema teko a maljedrosa.
S.TRANSL: But the two of them couldn’t get down.

S.FORM: "kemuda itjen, qalian?" aya tiamadju.
"kemoda itjen, qalian?" aya tiamadjo.
S.TRANSL: They said: “What shall we do, friend?”

S.FORM: matsingul anga sakamaya i vavaw ta kamaya.
macingol anga sakamaya i vavaw ta kamaya.
S.TRANSL: They were just stranded up the mango tree,

S.FORM: qemaung aza mareqali.
qemaong aza mareqali.
S.TRANSL: and they cried.

S.FORM: ka inika makayanga sema teku, maselem anga sakamaya.
ka inika makayanga sema teko, maselem anga sakamaya.
S.TRANSL: They couldn’t get down, and it got dark.

S.FORM: kipakiman anga na matjałałak.
kipakiman anga na matjaljaljak.
S.TRANSL: Their parents looked for them.

S.FORM: manu patadałan naza mareqali aza kina kata kama a namasisapuy.
mano patadaljan naza mareqali aza kina kata kama a namasisapoy.
S.TRANSL: The friends could see their mothers and fathers holding torches.

S.FORM: "ła qunu ła qunu, inu mun?" aya za kama.
"lja qono lja qono, ino mon?" aya za kama.
S.TRANSL: The father(s) said: “Children children, where are you?”

S.FORM: tjału tjai teku tjayamadju.
tjaljo tjai teko tjayamadjo.
S.TRANSL: They came right below them.

S.FORM: "aki pasainu a mareka tja ałak?
"aki pasaino a mareka tja aljak?
S.TRANSL: “Where have our children gone to?

S.FORM: aki matsay?
aki macay?
S.TRANSL: Are they dead?

S.FORM: aki semainu?" aya za matjałałak na mareqali.
aki semaino?" aya za matjaljaljak na mareqali.
S.TRANSL: Where have they gone?” the friends’ parents said.

S.FORM: naqełetep aza mareqali taza rekutjan taza matjałałak.
naqeljetep aza mareqali taza rekotjan taza matjaljaljak.
S.TRANSL: The friends kept quiet for fear of their parents.

S.FORM: manu vaik a sema umaq aza matjałałak.
mano vaik a sema omaq aza matjaljaljak.
S.TRANSL: So the parents went home.

S.FORM: ka zemuker i umaq, pasemalaw taza i umaq: "neka tia mareqali; matsay kaumaya," aya taza taqałaqałan.
ka zemoker i omaq, pasemalaw taza i omaq: "neka tia mareqali; macay kaomaya," aya taza taqaljaqaljan.
S.TRANSL: When they got home they told the people there: “There is no sign of the friends; perhaps they are dead,” they said to their fellow-villagers.

S.FORM: pai ka małianga vaik anga kemim aza taqałaqałan.
pai ka maljianga vaik anga kemim aza taqaljaqaljan.
S.TRANSL: So next day the villagers went to look for them,

S.FORM: manu patsun aza maḍusa.
mano pacon aza madrosa.
S.TRANSL: and two of them saw the children (or and the two (children) saw them coming).

S.FORM: "uzai a łavingan i vavaw ta kamaya," aya za qaliqali.
"ozai a ljavingan i vavaw ta kamaya," aya za qaliqali.
S.TRANSL: These others said: “There’s some monkeys up a mango tree.

S.FORM: "ari tja kuangaw," aya tiamadju.
"ari tja koangaw," aya tiamadjo.
S.TRANSL: Let’s shoot them.”

S.FORM: ka zukeren, mavan aza maḍusa.
ka zokeren, mavan aza madrosa.
S.TRANSL: When they got there, they saw it was the two children.

S.FORM: "pindjek sa suledjeledji.
"pindjek sa soledjeledji.
S.TRANSL: They said to the two friends: “You silly fools! (?)

S.FORM: aki manu łavingan, aya men tjanumun.
aki mano ljavingan, aya men tjanomon.
S.TRANSL: We thought you were monkeys.

S.FORM: uzi kemikim amen a taqałaqałan tjanumun.
ozi kemikim amen a taqaljaqaljan tjanomon.
S.TRANSL: All the village is searching for you;

S.FORM: manu i vavaw mun tusa kamaya.
mano i vavaw mon tosa kamaya.
S.TRANSL: and here you are up a mango tree.

S.FORM: kełu sateku," ayain aza mareqali.
keljo sateko," ayain aza mareqali.
S.TRANSL: Come on down.”

S.FORM: "inika men a makaya," aya za mareqali.
"inika men a makaya," aya za mareqali.
S.TRANSL: The friends said: “We can’t get down.”

S.FORM: sisan tjekezanga, sa sateku anga.
sisan tjekezanga, sa sateko anga.
S.TRANSL: A ladder was made for them, and they got down. (Moral: We mustn’t be greedy or steal.)
